item.title: PS3 vs. Xbox 360
item.dc:creator: Jeannotvb
item.description:
Android11x:

You’d think so, but you’d be wrong. Lemme get things straight with Xbox Live.

There are two kinds of Live membership:

[COLOR=‘Silver’]Silver: Free, need internet connection + these perks

  • Go online free of charge.
  • Register a unique gamertag and set up your individual gamer card to keep track of your gaming accomplishments.
  • Engage in one-on-one Voice Over Internet Protocol (VOIP) and chat with your friends via the Xbox 360 Headset.
  • Access Xbox Live Marketplace, download and view demos, trailers, and purchase classic and casual games over Xbox Live Arcade using Microsoft Points.
  • Preview Xbox Live Gold during free weekend trials.
  • Download auto updates and free downloads for your Xbox 360 games.
  • Access Xbox Live Message Center where you can send and receive voice and text messages from other members.
  • Compare gaming stats and achievements against other Xbox Live members.
  • Use your friends list to see who’s online.
    [COLOR=‘Gold’]
    Gold: $50 annual free, need internet connect + these perks
  • Play your Xbox 360 multiplayer games online with the premiere online gaming service.
  • Use the brand new TrueSkill Matchmaking system to play against opponents with similar skills, personalities, and gaming tastes.
  • Give player feedback to rate your teammates and opponents on their sportsmanship, abilities, and conduct to influence matchmaking.
  • Play select original Xbox games online (the Xbox 360 Hard Drive is required).
  • Get access to exclusive Gold Member content.
  • Engage in video chat.
  • Enjoy all the Xbox Live Silver features (above).

And I’m not bashing the PS3… much. This is a versus thread and I’m giving information that could essentially help someone make the decision on purchasing a console. I believe the Xbox has “more bang for your buck” if you’re looking for gaming (for both casuals and hardcores, media viewing, user-friendliness, and a fulfilling online experience.

Xbox is just as much, if not, more a home entertainment center than the PS3. What it boils down to is what you are looking for in a console. I find that Xbox caters to the majority of mine and many others’ needs. Also, Microsoft has been nothing, but nice to me since I got the “[COLOR=‘Red’]Red Ring Of Death” after having the 360 for 3 years. Sent me a new one, free of charge even though I had surpassed my warranty.

You haven’t really shown me that it’s cheaper. But ok.

item.title: PS3 vs. Xbox 360
item.dc:creator: Surplus
item.description:
I have a 360 I wish I hadn’t have bought it not that I wish I had bought a PS3. Really this generation of consoles is total garbage. Don’t feed me that motion control is innovation bullshit. Its a new form of input instead of pressing a button I wave my arm. The increase in immersion can be likened to better graphics, in the end its still all about the game design.

The big problem here is that consoles are bottle necking themselves with such strict regulation. Microsoft is a total ass-face about it but at least Sony shows improvements with the allowing Steam. With CoD:MW 2 (I thought about removing the face but I feel it is appropriate) not allowing dedicated server support or mods for PC just makes me more angry. Consoles need to find a way to allow all that great custom content and freedom that PC games have; if they don’t do that it won’t take people long to realize the illusion of a low price and simplicity that a console supplies and they will switch to PC.

My point being consoles all suck, pick your poison. There is very little improvement from the last generation of consoles in terms of the platform. The only thing that has really changed is a wider software support of online play.

item.title: PS3 vs. Xbox 360
item.dc:creator: Maxey
item.description:
Microsoft focused on the gaming part of the 360 more than Sony with their PS3.

When Sony launched the PS3, their marketing logic was to announce it as a multimedia system, rather than just a game console that also plays blu ray movies. That ended up alienating consumers, thinking that Sony downplayed the console gaming part. Add to that a weak online component on launch, a selection of multiplatform titles that performed better on the 360 because the PS3’s architecture is tricky to program for and a really steep price tag, and you end up with a system that suffers from identity crisis and ended up disappointing gamers.

The 360, however, was marketed from the start as a straight gaming machine, with a strong online support, far easier to program for and cheaper to buy.

If you’re a straight up gamer and look at them in that perspective, which system you end up getting?
